intro: Fimbristylis fusca var. hispidissima, commonly known as the hairy fringed sedge, is a perennial herbaceous plant native to tropical and subtropical regions. It belongs to the family Cyperaceae, which includes sedges and related plants. The plant typically grows in wetland or marshy environments, thriving in moist, nutrient-rich soils. Its leaves are narrow and grass-like, with a distinctive hairy texture on the lower stem and leaf sheaths. The inflorescence consists of a dense cluster of small, three-ranked spikelets, characteristic of the sedge family.
